nonMonitoredImpact.title: Non-monitored Impact
nonMonitoredImpact.subtitle: These outcomes are natural by-products of the primary impact above, but will not be measured or verified.

landManagementActions.title: Land Management Actions
landManagementActions.subtitle: This is how the project developers are planning to achieve the primary impact.

projects.name: Woodburn
glanceText: Improved co-benefits significantly with Soil Health ranking as excellent, Ecosystem Health as good, and Animal Welfare as excellent.

developer.name: Impact Ag
developer.description: Impact Ag utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital on assets under management or advisory.

steward.name: Wilmot Cattle Co.
steward.description: Wilmot Cattle Company is an innovative, regenerative, grass-fed beef business.

projects.tagline: Grant and Tanya Wickham have managed Woodburn since 2011

quote.text: We like to run our cattle at high density rate, then let the grass come back, usually giving each paddock 60 days rest before the cattle come back.

projects.shortDescription: Woodburn is a 2,555 ha beef breeding enterprise situated north of Walcha on the New England tablelands. Woodburn was purchased in 2011 with the goal of breeding our own home grown grass fed beef. The annual average rainfall of 730mm and 1,120m above sea level with lightly timbered country comprising of basalt and sandy loam soils.
projects.longDescription:
Grant has been managing Woodburn since it was purchased by the Wilmot Cattle Co in 2011 and has overseen the transition from convention management systems to regenerative agricultural practices. Grant and Tanya both have an innate connection to the land having come from rural NSW Mid North Coast. Grant has worked in the North West Slopes and Plains region in a managerial role bringing over 25 years experience to the team.

Grant has overseen the conversion of Woodburn's management strategies towards regenerative agricultural practices. This process excellerated from 2016 and has led to a general improvement in the farms producitivty and ecosystem health.
keyOutcomesActivities: Unique - avoiding double issuance through GIS tracking
Real - GHG impact is quantifiable and verifiable
Measurable - each credit represents one ton of CO2e
Permanent - 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant
Additional - a new practice adopted from pre-approved list
Leakage - de minimis in agricultural land management

actions.name: Time Controlled Rotational Grazing
actions.description: Since 2013, Wilmot Cattle Co has implemented time controlled rotational grazing at the Wilmot property. Effectively mimicking natural herding behaviours, time controlled rotational grazing is the practice of moving large herds of animals across the landscape, grazing pastures for very short periods of time, allowing long rest periods, enabling adequate plant recovery. Stocking rate is adjusted frequently to match the feed available and growth rate of the plant. When managed well, this grazing system increases groundcover, biomass, plant diversity, animal and plant nutrition, soil health, water infiltration and soil organic carbon. A more complete explanation of the science, monitoring tools and management practices is provided below.

actions.name: Decrease Paddock Size
actions.description: Decreased paddock sizes enable effective grazing at a controllable density. Wilmot Farm has adopted a paddock subdivision program with an average paddock size of 22 hectares.

actions.name: Increase Stock Density
actions.description: Carefully managed, high stock densities lead to evenly grazed pastures, nutrient recycling, increases in pasture health and performance by trampling (or recycling) a higher proportion of biomass, and evenly distributing dung and urine (nutrients).

actions.name: Monitor Pasture Growth
actions.description: Accurate measurement of pasture growth (available feed) determines the density of animals and length of time in a paddock.

actions.name: Manage Grazing Periods
actions.description: To ensure effectively implemented grazing practices and management practices records, Wilmot Farm utilizes the online tool Maia Grazing. Maia Grazing uses climatic data and field observations to determine pasture growth and optimal stocking rates, tracks stock movements, and ensures the stocking rate does not exceed the carrying capacity of each paddock.

impact.name: Soil Organic Carbon
impact.description: Organic matter contributes to nutrient retention and turnover, soil structure, moisture retention and availability, degradation of pollutants, carbon sequestration and soil resilience.

impact.name: Animal Welfare
impact.description: Animal welfare is an important component in a well managed grazing enterprise. Low stress stock handling techniques have been adopted to ensure animals have higher quality life.

impact.name: Ecosystem Health
impact.description: In the ecological realm, ‘health’ is characterized by system integrity and the exhibition of certain fundamental properties of self-organizing complex systems.

impact.name: Soil Health
impact.description: The capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans. An annual soil monitoring program has been in place since 2013.

creditClass.name: CarbonPlus Grasslands
creditClass.description:
Livestock grazing covers over 3.3 billion hectares, or 25 percent of the world’s land area. Managed grazing practices can reverse land degradation, enhance net carbon sequestration, and improve soil and vegetation quality.

Under managed grazing, carbon sequestration potential is estimated between 16.4 and 26 Gt CO2e sequestered in the period between 2020-2050.

This credit is designed to significantly increase the amount of hectares under managed grazing worldwide. To that end, the methodology relies on remote sensing to substantially reduce the cost of monitoring carbon sequestration while maintaining scientific rigor.

projects.name: Wilmot
glanceText: Improved co-benefits significantly with Soil Health ranking as excellent, Ecosystem Health as good, and Animal Welfare as excellent.

developer.name: Impact Ag
developer.description: Impact Ag utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital on assets under management or advisory.

steward.name: Wilmot Cattle Co.
steward.description: Wilmot Cattle Company is an innovative, regenerative, grass-fed beef business.

projects.tagline: Stuart Austin & Trisha Cowley have managed Wilmot since 2016

quote.text: We feel privileged to have the opportunity to manage cattle in a truly holistic and regenerative way on such a remarkable property.

projects.shortDescription: Wilmot is an extraordinary property high in the New England Tablelands at Ebor, New South Wales, Australia. Set on 1,854ha and at approximately 1,200m above sea level, average annual rainfall of 1,200mm, highly fertile volcanic basalt soils, and complimented by a series of pristine spring fed, year-round natural waterways including five waterfalls, it is quite simply a unique environment for growing cattle.
projects.longDescription:
Stu & Trish are the management team behind Wilmot Cattle Co and are driven by the exciting ecological opportunities they can foresee for the business. They have a wholehearted belief in regenerative agriculture and the benefits it will bring to the industry globally, as we collectively work to heal what has largely become a degraded landscape. They having a burning desire to succeed in agriculture and are very ambitious in the growth and development plans they have for Wilmot Cattle Co.

While Stu has managed the day to day operations of Wilmot since 2016, and now presides over the portfolio of all three properties in a General Manager capacity, Trish works tirelessly behind the scenes ensuring a high level of rigour around the data collection, management, and analysis of every aspect of the business. They firmly believe that you cannot manage what you don’t measure and as such, the integrity of the data is paramount.

In their spare time they enjoy exploring the natural wonders of Wilmot, including its five waterfalls and large areas of virtually native bushland, with their two kids Harry and Poppy. They all gain great satisfaction from discovering new species of plants and learning about their role in the ecosystem.
